subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Sweet! Now I know who to go to ;)

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: =
Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 4:56 PM
  S=
ubject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules





        Yep, that's exactly=
 what that comparison does.  It compares each and every byte (all their 
  =
      bits) from file to file.  If the same bytes are in both files, in the=
 same places, they are the same.  One tiny little difference, and it tells =
you.

        --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombieghos=
tresearch.com> wrote:


          From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombi=
eghostresearch.com>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
 =
         To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, =
3:42 PM



          You can actually tell if the bytes themselves are diff=
erent? If so, that would definitely satisfy me that everything was the same=
.

            ----- Original Message ----- 
            From: Rj 
        =
    To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
            Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 4:=
32 PM
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON=



                  If the audio had been resampled, you could expect less=
 bytes, or different bytes, but not the same number of the same bytes.  Tha=
t's why comparing the bytes in both files can rule that out, if no changes =
are found.



                  --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <apr=
il@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                    From: April=
 Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                    Sub=
ject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
                    =
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                    Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009=
, 3:27 PM



                    Yeah-I know about the file size comparison=
. Obviously if the file size became smaller, we know for sure there has bee=
n loss, except if the file had been saved to a lossless compression type, s=
uch as from RAW to TIFF in photo files.

                    I just don't f=
ully trust the bit comparison because I don't trust that the bytes haven't =
been resampled using interpolation, such as we discussed earlier. But that =
is largely because I have no clue at that level of things what is actually =
going on.

                    All I know about this I know from Graphic De=
sign experience and working with photo files, so I only have that knowledge=
 to use to compare. I no nothing about actual programming language, Unix, o=
r stuff like that.

                    April

                      ----- =
Original Message ----- 
                      From: Rj 
                   =
   To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                      Sent: Sunday, May 10=
, 2009 4:13 PM
                      Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading =
rules-ATTENTION JON


                            They are not necessarily =
the same bytes, but I was proposing a quick check just to see if the files =
were in the same ballpark.  Look at it the other way: if the number of byte=
s were DIFFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD changed, and you could stop=
 testing.  But if the number of bytes are the same, it tends to indicate th=
e files are likely the same, but you still need a low level file comparison=
 to be sure.

                            My method is to compare the files=
 using the CMP command in unix.  There are many programs to compare files, =
but you have to be careful not to use one that does a line-by-line compare =
(or a comparison meant for text files), since text files can be different a=
t a low level, but look essential the same in an editor (because of the way=
 spaces and tabs and new lines work between editors and platforms).

      =
                      But anyway, the way to compare is with a program that=
 can compare binary files, not text files.


                            --=
- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>=
 wrote:


                              From: April Abercrombie <april@aber=
crombiegh ostresearch. com>
                              Subject: Re: [EVP=
-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
                              To: =
EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                              Date: Sunday, May 10=
, 2009, 2:42 PM



                              So if the number of bytes =
match then they are the same bytes? See where my confusion comes in?

     =
                         How does one do a bit-level comparison? Is there a=
 program that does that, or is there some way of comparison by looking at t=
he file's properties?

                                ----- Original Messa=
ge ----- 
                                From: Rj 
                       =
         To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                                Sent=
: Sunday, May 10, 2009 3:35 PM
                                Subject: Re:=
 [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON


                           =
     A file's content, it's integrity, is simply the bytes (and their bits)=
 in the file.  If the file's content integrity is changed, that is, by defi=
nition, changing the bytes.  If the bytes in there are not changed, then th=
at integrity has not changed.

                                It is possib=
le to mess with other things about a file (like its name, its suffix, or it=
s ownership) but this does not effect the contents, and so would not affect=
 that integrity, or the sound of the file (assuming you could read it at al=
l after changing the ownership, or the suffix, etc).

                     =
           When you do your tests, if you cannot do a bit level comparison,=
 I would recommend at least checking the file sizes.  If they are identical=
, there is a very high probability that the content has not changed.




  =
                              --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april=
@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                F=
rom: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
             =
                   Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JO=
N
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
            =
                    Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:28 PM



                =
                Admittedly I do not know much about bit-level comparisons, =
what they can or can't show so I will have to leave that to you. I have dou=
bts because I worry once a file's integrity has been messed with, I wonder =
that even though the bits match, maybe that doesn't mean they are the same =
quality as the original. I really don't know though what is possible or imp=
ossible when it comes to this area.

                                "It is=
 probably possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do lossy=
 audio compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to =
help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compressio=
n from an attachment would be very unusual."

                             =
   The problem I have is that not just from Jon, but I have heard it from o=
ther people, and a professional and they all said that loss is possible. Fr=
om all that, my conclusion was that maybe in some cases loss was possible.
=

                                However, your arguments do put doubt back =
into my mind, which pisses me off, because I had originally argued feverish=
ly for no loss, then I heard different from different sources and decided t=
o do what I thought was the right thing by contacting a third party profess=
ional. So after all that, I decided I was licked and had to eat crow.

    =
                            Now I am back at square one, from the other sid=
e LOL!!! Computer people have been wrong in the past.


                   =
             "It is probably possible to set up an email compression scheme=
 that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  I=
f you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I se=
e, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual."

          =
                      I have not tested it from my computer, as I haven't h=
ad any problems with loss. I would really like to have Jon work with us on =
this, because he was the original person who told me I was wrong.

        =
                        But I will test it from my side. I will send a wav =
file to one of my other addresses. Then I will download and compare. If I t=
hink I hear a difference, then maybe I can have you do a bit-level comparis=
on on the files.

                                Either way, I am going to=
 get to the bottom of this.



                                ----- Origin=
al Message ----- 
                                From: Rj 
               =
                 To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                            =
    Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:59 PM
                                Subj=
ect: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON


                   =
             Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit-level comparison.  A=
n audio file is just a file of bytes, that is later interpreted by an audio=
 player.  Two files with the exact same contents, whether they are audio or=
 image or a dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable from each other.  Tha=
t is, if I copied the contents of one to a new file, and the contents of th=
e other to a new file, and asked you which file each came from, there would=
 be no way to tell.  Even the audio player could not tell.  The data is ide=
ntical, and so the sound (or the picture, etc) would be identical.

       =
                         Yes I did listen to the results, but that is not t=
he best test (they sounded identical, but that is a subjective opinion).  T=
he real test is compring the contents.  Identical contents means indentical=
 data, means identical audio.

                                It is probab=
ly possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio =
compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help te=
st your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from =
an attachment would be very unusual.


                                --- =
On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> w=
rote:


                                From: April Abercrombie <april@aber=
crombiegh ostresearch. com>
                                Subject: Re: [E=
VP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
                                =
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, =
May 10, 2009, 1:50 PM



                                I have not persona=
lly experienced the loss myself. Jon from this list is the one who original=
ly told me about it. I have also heard of it happening to a few other peopl=
e. After my conversation with Jon, I talked to a computer professional, and=
 he told me that you can experience loss in attached files.

              =
                  I don't know if you would be able to tell loss of quality=
 in an audio file with a bit-level comparison. Just because the data has be=
en replaced, doesn't have to mean it is perfect.

                         =
       Did you listen to the before and after results?

                   =
             Jon-Please relay your experience with the loss of quality on e=
mailed files.


                                ----- Original Message ----=
- 
                                From: Rj 
                              =
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                                Sent: Sunda=
y, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-I=
TC] File uploading rules


                                I can't vouch fo=
r your computer or servers, but I just did some tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav=
 file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once allowing compression, and once turni=
ng it off.   I was able to verify that one was compressed and one was not, =
by checking the sizes when they arrived at Yahoo. Once they came back to MS=
N, I then did a bit-level comparison of the original, and the ones sent aro=
und email.  They were all identical, which indicates lossless compression.
=

                                If you have a file you'd like me to test f=
or you, let me know.  But I wouldn't take someone's word for how your serve=
r's work, without testing them yourself.



                               =
 --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. c=
om> wrote:


                                From: April Abercrombie <april=
@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                                Subject: R=
e: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To: EVP-I=
TC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2=
009, 12:50 PM



                                For executables, you may b=
e right. However, for wav files, the compression during email is not loss l=
ess. 

                                I used to think as you do, in that t=
he emailed attachment of a wav file would not loose anything. After a lengt=
hy discourse with another member here, I learned that I was wrong. The reas=
on why I did not realize it in the first place is that when I would email a=
 wav file, I would intentionally keep it in very small segments, to keep fi=
le size down. This was just for ease of transfer. But because of this, I ha=
d not experienced any noticeable loss.

                                Now=
 it may be in some cases, depending on the servers or what have you that th=
e file goes through, that the loss may be less or more. But once the attach=
ment is downloaded, the quality has been found to be less then the original=
 wav.

                                Again though you can only really tel=
l when the wav file is large.

                                ----- Origin=
al Message ----- 
                                From: Rj 
               =
                 To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                            =
    Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
                                Subj=
ect: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


                                T=
he kind of compression that occurs during an email attachment is "lossless"=
: it compress the file cleverly without losing information.  For example, i=
f I had a program in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, it could co=
mpress it.  But if it lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would not e=
xecute again after it was uncompressed on the other side.

                =
                This kind of compression does things like looking for commo=
n patterns in the file, and replacing them with a token.  A rough example w=
ould be if it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replace a=
ll the occurances with say $HN1.  And also write a little dictionary in the=
re someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".

                          =
      When the file gets to its destination it can be uncompressed, and all=
 occurences of $HN1 are replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".  So it was compress=
ed (instead of 14 characters each, it only needed 4, plus the dictionary), =
but lost no data.

                                Some formats, like jpeg =
and mp3. are not lossless.  Depending on the level of compression, some lev=
el of data is lost, and so cannot be recovered or reconstructed later.

   =
                             Rick



                                --- On=
 Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wro=
te:


                                From: April Abercrombie <april@abercr=
ombiegh ostresearch. com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP=
-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yaho=
ogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10=
:26 AM



                                Another thing:

                 =
               I recently found this out. When you email a file, if it is n=
ot saved as a compressed format, the email filtering process will actually =
compress the file automatically.

                                So even i=
f you have attached a wav. file, it will loose resolution over the email pr=
ocess. It will not sound exactly the same as the original wav. file. How mu=
ch it differs depends on the size of the file you are attaching. If it is a=
 very large file, it will sound much different.

                          =
      The only exception to this is if the wav. file is small enough that t=
he filtering process will ignore it. It has to be pretty small though, like=
 under 1 MB (I am not exactly sure of the threshold).

                    =
            The best way to share files over the internet if you want them =
as close to the original as possible is to upload them directly to a websit=
e.

                                ----- Original Message ----- 
         =
                       From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-IT=
C@yahoogroups .com 
                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2=
009 10:54 AM
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File up=
loading rules



                                Pixelization doesn't clean=
-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a picture of a field of flowe=
rs, and beginning to add levels or pixelization to the picture.  Soon, you =
would not be able to tell there were flowers there at all.  You would see a=
 lot of colored blocks.

                                Or in the other di=
rection, imagine you are looking at a competely randomize bunch of pixes on=
 your screen: a complete screen of truely random static snow.  Pixelizing t=
his, after a while, you would again start to see colored blocks.

         =
                       What's happening is that it is processing an area of=
 the image, taking (for instance) the average value of that entire area, an=
d replacing all the blocks in that area with the average.  In video process=
ing, this would result in a field of multi-colored flowers being replaced b=
y, for instance, a big greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to flowers=
.  In the noise example, it maybe replace all the random pixels with anothe=
r big greyish-bluish block.  If you did not know beforehand what the origin=
al picture was, you couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was really a=
 field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixel=
s.

                                It works the same with the sound files.=
  Taking something as complex as speech, and replacing frequencies with the=
ir averages, loses the speech the farther you go, until you head strange fl=
uctuating square waves.  Doing the same to random static will eventually pr=
oduce the same thing.  And random fluctuating square waves can sound a bit =
like speech - or at least, you could have fun sharing with each other what =
you thing they 'sound like'.





                                --- On Su=
n, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                  =
              From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                   =
             Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                  =
              To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                =
Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:29 AM


                                I alw=
ays save the whole file in wav format then do my clips as mp3. Then I have =
the original for analysis. 

                                As far as pixe=
lization of non sounds/white noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated =
by them as well LOL. Water is a form of white noise. I seem to remember som=
e experiments done with blank tapes/film, no recording done yet there were =
voices/images there. I find it all interesting.

                          =
      Just a thought. Ok off to work now!
                                M=
isty

                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yah=
oo. com> wrote:


                                From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo.=
 com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading=
 rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
       =
                         Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


           =
                     Be a bit careful of formats like mp3 if you are doing =
a detailed analysis of the sounds though.   While some formats (like wav) c=
an store the audio very close to the way it was recorded, formats like mp3 =
compress the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic details.  This ma=
y not be a big deal in music, where the audio is fairly clear to begin with=
.  But with sound sources with a lot of noise (like evps), this can not onl=
y obscure any real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white noise) and m=
ake them start to sound like speech.

                                So mp=
3 might be good for sharing the data, once you've already formed an opinion=
 based on an analysis of the wav file.  But mp3 is not good as a medium for=
 analysis.  It can lead to many false positives and misinterpretations.

  =
                              --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@=
 yahoo.com> wrote:


                                From: Misty Dawn <bull=
etbabea@ yahoo.com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] =
File uploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroup=
s .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM
=


                                Thanks =3D)

                            =
     You will get the hang of it. Kristen is right thats how you save it. F=
or most softwares its under save as or export as. If you still have trouble=
 use one of the links I posted to help ya out.

                           =
     Misty

aol. com <SnowfireL@aol. com> wrote:

                                Misty

    =
            <TD vAlign=3Dtop>If the audio had been resampled, you could 
  =
                expect less bytes, or different bytes, but not the same num=
ber 
                  of the same bytes.  That's why comparing the by=
tes in 
                  both files can rule that out, if no changes are 
=
                  found.<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, April 
    =
              Abercrombie <I><<A

to=3Dapril@..."

research.com">april@abercrombiegh 
                  ostresearch. com</A>&g=
t;</I></B> wrote:<BR>

yle=3D"BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px solid"><BR>From:

                    <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">Yeah-I k=
now about the 
                    file size comparison. Obviously if the f=
ile size became 
                    smaller, we know for sure there has be=
en loss, except if the 
                    file had been saved to a l=
ossless compression 
                    type, such as from RAW t=
o TIFF in photo 
                    files.</FONT></DIV>
                  =
  <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
             =
       <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">I just don't fully trust 
  =
                  the bit comparison because I don't trust that the bytes 
=
                    haven't been resampled using interpolation, such as we =

                    discussed earlier. But that is largely because I have =
no 
                    clue at that level of things what is actually going=
 
                    on.</FONT></DIV>
                    <DIV><FONT size=
=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                    <DIV><FONT=
 size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">All I know about this I 
                    =
know from Graphic Design experience and working with photo 
               =
     files, so I only have that knowledge to use to compare. 
        =
            I no nothing about actual programming language, Unix, or 
     =
               stuff like that.</FONT></DIV>

               =
           <TD vAlign=3Dtop>They are not necessarily the same 
            =
                bytes, but I was proposing a quick check just to see 
     =
                       if the files were in the same ballpark.  Look 
=
                            at it the other way: if the number of bytes wer=
e 
                            DIFFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD cha=
nged, 
                            and you could stop testing.  But if=
 the number 
                            of bytes are the same, it tends to=
 indicate the 
                            files are likely the same, but y=
ou still need a low 
                            level file comparison to b=
e sure.<BR><BR>My method 
                            is to compare the fil=
es using the CMP command in 
                            unix.  There =
are many programs to compare 
                            files, but you ha=
ve to be careful not to use one 
                            that does a li=
ne-by-line compare (or a comparison 
                            meant for =
text files), since text files can be 
                            different=
 at a low level, but look essential the 
                            same i=
n an editor (because of the way spaces and 
                            tab=
s and new lines work between editors and 
                            platf=
orms).<BR><BR>But anyway, the way to compare is 
                          =
  with a program that can compare binary files, not 
                      =
      text files.<BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, April 
               =
             Abercrombie <I><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
         =
                   com></I></B> wrote:<BR>

        <TR>
                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>A file's cont=
ent, it's integrity, 
                                is simply the bytes (=
and their bits) in the 
                                file.  If the =
file's content integrity is 
                                changed, that =
is, by definition, changing the 
                                bytes.&nbs=
p; If the bytes in there are not 
                                changed, =
then that integrity has not 
                                changed.<BR><B=
R>It is possible to mess with 
                                other things=
 about a file (like its name, its 
                                suffix, =
or its ownership) but this does not 
                                effect=
 the contents, and so would not affect 
                                tha=
t integrity, or the sound of the file 
                                (ass=
uming you could read it at all after 
                                chang=
ing the ownership, or the suffix, 
                                etc).<BR=
><BR>When you do your tests, if you 
                                cannot=
 do a bit level comparison, I would 
                                recomm=
end at least checking the file 
                                sizes.&nbsp=
; If they are identical, there is a 
                                very h=
igh probability that the content has not 
                                c=
hanged.<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                                =
5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                                <I><april@ab=
ercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                                com></I></B> w=
rote:<BR>
                                <BLOCKQUOTE 
                    =
            style=3D"BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px solid"><BR>From:

May

has been

hough the bits

ean they are the same

nal. I really don't know

ssible or impossible when it

       <TABLE border=3D0 cellSpacing=3D0 cellPadding=3D0>
                 =

               =
                 <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Yes you can tell loss of quality 
       =
                         by a bit-level comparison.  An audio file 
  =
                              is just a file of bytes, that is later 
     =
                           interpreted by an audio player.  Two files =

                                with the exact same contents, whether they=
 are 
                                audio or image or a dababase or an ex=
e, are 
                                indistinguishable from each other.&=
nbsp; That 
                                is, if I copied the contents of=
 one to a new 
                                file, and the contents of th=
e other to a new 
                                file, and asked you which=
 file each came from, 
                                there would be no wa=
y to tell.  Even the 
                                audio player cou=
ld not tell.  The data is 
                                identical, =
and so the sound (or the picture, 
                                etc) wou=
ld be identical.<BR><BR>Yes I did listen 
                                t=
o the results, but that is not the best test 
                             =
   (they sounded identical, but that is a 
                                =
subjective opinion).  The real test is 
                              =
  compring the contents.  Identical contents 
                        =
        means indentical data, means identical 
                           =
     audio.<BR><BR>It is probably possible to set up 
                     =
           an email compression scheme that does do lossy 
                =
                audio compression.  My tests show my setup 
          =
                      does not.  If you'd like me to help test 
      =
                          your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, =

                                lossy compression from an attachment would=
 be 
                                very unusual.<BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun=
, 5/10/09, 
                                April Abercrombie <I><april@=
abercrombiegh 
                                ostresearch. com></I></B>=
 wrote:<BR>
                                <BLOCKQUOTE 
                  =

]

                                EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com<BR>Date: Sunday=
, May 
                                10, 2009, 1:50 PM<BR><BR>
          =

                            =
    <DIV id=3Dygrp-text>
                                <P></P>
          =
                      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">I have not 
 =
                               personally experienced the loss myself. Jon =
from 
                                this list is the one who originally t=
old me 
                                about it. I have also heard of=
 it happening 
                                to a few other people. =
After my 
                                conversation with Jon, =
I talked to a 
                                computer professional, and h=
e told me that you 
                                can experience loss in =
attached 
                                files.</FONT></DIV>
             =

e=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>

                     =

               =

     <TR>
                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>I can't vouch fo=
r your computer 
                                or servers, but I just did=
 some tests, and sent 
                                a 2.1MB wav file fro=
m MSN to Yahoo and back, 
                                once allowing com=
pression, and once turning it 
                                off. &n=
bsp; I was able to verify that one 
                                was com=
pressed and one was not, by checking the 
                                s=
izes when they arrived at Yahoo. Once they came 
                          =
      back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison 
                     =
           of the original, and the ones sent around 
                     =
           email.  They were all identical, which 
                   =
             indicates lossless compression.<BR><BR>If you 
               =
                 have a file you'd like me to test for you, let 
          =
                      me know.  But I wouldn't take someone's 
       =
                         word for how your server's work, without testing 
=
                                them yourself.<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun=

owever, for wav

=
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
                      =
          face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                         =
       <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">I used to 
                 =
               think as you do, in that the emailed 
                      =
          attachment of a wav file would not loose 
                  =
              anything. After a lengthy discourse with another 
           =
                     member here, I learned that I was wrong. The 
        =
                        reason why I did not realize it in the 
      =
                          first place is that when I would email a wav 
   =
                             file, I would intentionally keep it in very 
 =
                               small segments, to keep file size down. This=
 was 
                                just for ease of transfer. But becaus=
e of this, 
                                I had not experienced any notic=
eable 
                                loss.</FONT></DIV>
                 =
               <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
                                face=3D=
"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT=
 size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">Now it may 
                                b=
e in some cases, depending on the servers or 
                             =
   what have you that the file goes through, that 
                        =
        the loss may be less or more. But once the 
                       =
         attachment is 
                                downloaded, th=
e quality has been 
                                found to be l=
ess then the original 
                                wav.</FONT></DIV>

        face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
